question: Fly ball.
answer: Fly ball.

question: Line drive.
answer: Line drive.

question: Ground ball.
answer: Ground ball.

question: Home run!
answer: Hone rone!

question: What'd you tell him?
answer: I told him to grip the ball more gently. Like a tit. Pedro Berroa. Third year. Hasn't developed like we hoped.

question: How much he sign for?
answer: Forty-five.

question: Jesus. These kids keep getting more expensive. How much did you sign for back in the day?
answer: 3000. When I was fifteen. Salvador Torres. Been practicing with the team for almost a week. Still raw, but he's got a lot of potential.

question: We gonna sign him?
answer: Soon. Soon. We want to play it low- key, see what his agent says.

question: How much you think?
answer: They've gotten two offers from other clubs. Agent says they were around a hundred. He's good.

question: What about him?
answer: Miguel Santos. Great arm. We signed him two years ago for fifteen.

question: Good deal. He throw any junk?
answer: Sugar! Show us your curve.

question: Not bad. Mind if I try something? Hey, kid, do you mind? May I?
answer: Give him the ball.

question: Spike curve. Gives you more rotation, more movement. You try.
answer: Vamos! Let's go! Pitch it!

question: I want to talk to you.
answer: I want talk to you.

question: Your performance in the mound is not as good as last year. What is the problem?
answer: Your performance in the mound is not good as last year. What is problem?

question: I don't know. Maybe my mechanic.
answer: I don't know. Maybe mechanic.

question: I want to give you a chance. It is up to you...
answer: I want to give you a chance. Is up to you...

question: Buenas, Miguelito! Do you have any good news for your mother?
answer: As a matter of fact, yes.

question: You're going to the United States?!
answer: Not yet, ma... But I learned how to throw a knuckle curve.

question: When will you finish this?
answer: Soon. It's just hard to find the time.

question: It's pretty.
answer: I'm trying to match the chairs my dad made, but I can't get it right.

question: Well, I think it's perfect.
answer: I'll make you another when I'm done.

question: And the rest of the house? How long till it's done?
answer: Um, another month, maybe two... You know we just did it where Abuela's room is going to be...

question: Don't tell me that!
answer: Why not? We can do it in mom's kitchen next. Right over there.

question: I hope you make it to the States this year.
answer: You hope? C'mon, there's nobody better, baby.

question: Okay, how about
answer: Now you're talkin'. And when I do, I'll buy a Cadillac, drive it through the ocean, and bring you back with me.

question: You can't drive a Cadillac on water.
answer: Yes! In the States they make cars that drive on water.

question: You're crazy.
answer: You'll see who's crazy. Just watch.

question: I want to see the snow. Does it snow in Kansas City?
answer: I don't know. But I'll take you to New York City. Yankee Stadium. It snows there. You wanta see me play in Yankee Stadium?

question: It doesn't snow during baseball season, silly.
answer: So we'll go for Christmas.

question: Promise?
answer: Next Christmas, we'll sail into Yankee Stadium in my Cadillac car-boat. Deal?

question: You are crazy! I liked it too, Javi.
answer: Then why'd you cut it last week? Or a new girl. Watch it, baby, that's a million-dollar arm you're messing with. This flabby rubberband can throw 95. What can yours do? 98? Then why you washing windshields now? I saw you try and bumrush Javy at the stoplight last week.

question: Then why'd you cut it last week? Or a new girl. Watch it, baby, that's a million-dollar arm you're messing with. This flabby rubberband can throw 95. What can yours do? 98? Then why you washing windshields now? I saw you try and bumrush Javy at the stoplight last week.
answer: I like this one. Good bat speed. Only twelve years old, out here four, five hours everyday. His mom tells me he's missing school. I say, yeah, but... have you seen his swing? I'm showing his older brother to the Yankees on Monday. They don't know what they missed with you. It's cool though. They'll be knocking on your door, offering millions when you turn into a superstar. You'll see...

question: Have you been to New York?
answer: Nothing like playing for a crowd of New Yorkers. They're even louder than Dominicans.

question: What's the city like?
answer: It's great. But you need to get to Kansas City before you start thinking about New York. Know what I mean?

question: You hear anything about spring training yet?
answer: Yep.

question: Hey, Sugar! They made me an offer.
answer: Good for you. Congratulations. How much they offer you?

question: 115,000. But, you know, my manager's taking, like, forty of it... What'd you sign for?
answer: Oh, you know, more or less the same. Did you get any other offers?

question: Yankees and Seattle, but not as much.
answer: Just don't get cocky. No one likes a dickhead... Welcome to the team.

question: So, why do they call you Sugar?
answer: Well it's like this... it started cause I'm sweet with the ladies. But mostly it's cause I got the sweetest knuckle curve in the whole Republic. He's just jealous. We got you a going away present.

question: Well it's like this... it started cause I'm sweet with the ladies. But mostly it's cause I got the sweetest knuckle curve in the whole Republic. He's just jealous. We got you a going away present.
answer: You should try Los Campos. I heard the Dodgers could use a new first baseman.

question: No caps indoors, son!
answer: Or you'll chop off your tongue.

question: Don't forget to call everyday. I want to know everything!
answer: Everything?

question: You know what I mean, dummy.
answer: Of course I'll be calling to keep you in check, make sure your grades don't slip.

question: When? What's your name?
answer: Don't give me any shit, kid. I taught you everything you know. I'm damn proud of you, kid. Your father would be, too.

question: Thanks. I owe it all to you.
answer: Not all. Just forty percent. I spent the best years of my life playing in the States. Life gives you a lot of opportunities, but baseball only gives you one. Enjoy every minute of it. How's your new curve?

question: It's pretty sweet.
answer: Good. Here...

question: What's this for?
answer: Your autograph. I'm kidding, you arrogant prick. It's so you can write your family... and me, too... if you feel like it.

question: Where's your boyfriend?
answer: Which one?

question: I don't know; the ugly one.
answer: Hector?

question: Okay, where's Hector?
answer: Some other party.

question: So what about the good-looking one?
answer: Mmm, Fernando... I think he's out there dancing with Sofia.

question: I'm proud of you, sis. You're going to do great things too. We all know it.
answer: I'm gonna miss you... C'mon, let's dance.

question: Never, never, never, drink from the hotel mini bar. That shit is expensive. You want beer, buy it at the store. You wanta see titties? They got magazines for that. Don't pay in the hotel.
answer: You boys ready?

question: The greatest thing about the States? You can order breakfast 24/7. French toast is the best. It's nothing like Dominican toast. French toast please.
answer: Who's next?

question: Brad Johnson. He just signed for a million dollars out of college. There's a lot of guys like that. But you can't let that intimidate you. Everyone knows Dominicans rule the game.
answer: What's this about Dominicans ruling the game?

question: Sammy, Manny, Pedro... Are you guys all from the same family?
answer: Look who's talking... Are these your brothers?

question: What, all Dominicans look the same, now? This is Miguel and Marcos. Up from Boca Chica.
answer: But you couldn't hang in Wichita.

question: I injured my knee, asshole. But I'm healthy now. You'll see.
answer: Fifty bucks you're back in Iowa next month.

question: I pitched against Rob Leonard today.
answer: No shit! You strike him out?

question: Yeah.
answer: Liar!

question: You don't believe me?
answer: No.

question: Well, I got one strike at least.
answer: So, do you like it there?

question: Mmmm... It's different.
answer: Different how?

question: I don't know. Just different. Like the food is really sweet.
answer: I thought you liked sweet things.

question: All the players are really good.
answer: But not like you.

question: No, not like me. Of course not... But they're pretty good.
answer: I miss you.

question: French toast, right?
answer: No... Egg. Egg, please.

question: Eggs. No problem. How would you like'm?
answer: Yes.

question: Um, okay, uh... Scrambled? Over easy? Sunny side up?
answer: French toast.

question: No eggs? You sure?
answer: French toast.

question: Alright, honey. French toast it is. Okay... This is scrambled. Scrambled.
answer: Scrambled.

question: Over easy.
answer: Over easy.

question: This one's tricky... Sunny-side-up. Sunny...
answer: Sunny...

question: Side...
answer: Side...

question: Up...
answer: Up.

question: Sunny side up... On the house.
answer: Thank you.

question: They're sending Antonio back.
answer: Shit. What about you guys?

question: Go take a look.
answer: I'm not with you guys?

question: Straight to Single A, bro. With Jorge. Congratulations.
answer: Where is Iowa? Can't I stay with you guys?

question: We've had Dominicans, Venezuelan boys, a Colombian, one from Panama, blacks and some Americans. Mostly Spanish boys, though. Johan Santana, Mendy Lopez and Ramon Martinez all stayed with us. Years ago.
answer: Last year we had this boy, Junior Sanchez. Nice boy. Decent with the glove, but couldn't bunt to save his life.

question: Two-for-twelve in sacrifice situations.
answer: Cost the team at least two victories.

question: Oh, that's being generous! I'd say four or five. Put your things down. I'll show you around. This is the kitchen. Help yourself to whatever you'd like. You can make a list of special foods you like to eat and put it here. Oh, and over here, this drawer is a little funny. You have to be careful or... This is the washer and the dryer. For your clothes. You put the soap in this one. Sopa. The other one's just hot air. Caliente. Your room is up here. El banyo. Your new cuarto. Bedroom. Do with it as you please. Just no girls. Chicas? No chicas.
answer: No drinking. No cervezas in the casa. No chicas in the bedroom.

question: I already told him that one.
answer: Okay. What about quiet time?

question: Right. There's no real curfew, but you must be quiet after ten.
answer: Diez. Shhhh... after diez.

question: Thank you.
answer: Everyone is so proud, Miguelito. It's all we can talk about.

question: Did you get the money?
answer: Of course.

question: Good. And Victor? Can he start construction on the house again? I'll be sending money every two weeks now.
answer: We just paid him. He's coming next week.

question: What about you? You get something for yourself like I said?
answer: Me? What do I need?

question: C'mon, mom...
answer: What?

question: You didn't get anything?
answer: Well, maybe I got some new shoes, but I'm not telling.

question: Yeah, okay.
answer: C'mon, bro, let's find you a suit.

question: I can't afford a suit.
answer: I didn't say buy a suit. I said find a suit. So when you make it big, you'll already know what looks good. Hot damn! That's what's up!

question: You like it?
answer: I love it! You look like an all-star, bro. "Starting pitcher for American League... from Kansas City... Miguel... 'Sugar'... Santos."

question: What about you, man? You try one.
answer: Me? Nah... I'm all washed up.

question: C'mon... Very nice.
answer: Dude. You have no idea. Just wait till we go to Big Muddy's.

question: Big Muddy's?
answer: You gotta be 21 to drink there. This is my old license. They won't know the difference.

question: Are you kidding me? Nobody's gonna believe I'm this ugly fool.
answer: Believe me; they won't know the difference.

question: Hey Miguel. C'mon inside.
answer: My first... strike-out.

question: Oh, Miguel... you're so sweet. Congratulations, I heard you pitched awesome. Hey everybody, this is Miguel. He's from the Dominican Republic, and now he pitches for the Swing.
answer: No. Thank you. Soccer? No. Baseball. Foos-ball?

question: Hey guys, let's get started. Everyone grab a seat. I'm so glad you all came. Last year, we didn't have half as many people in our group. So, I think this just goes to show the great work we've been doing in spreading the word. But this year, I want us to work harder. Now, I know a lot of you are studying for SATs or working on college applications. And all of that is important, but we need to remember that our spiritual accomplishments are more important. What we do in school or for a job... that's just a small part of who we are. We're only here by the grace of God, so let's get out there and share that grace.
answer: Mamaema. Very bad. Very bad word.

question: Mamaema. Very bad. Very bad word.
answer: Mama-ema? What's it mean?

question: Mmm... Like--
answer: Cocksucker?

question: Cock-sucker?
answer: Yeah, we say cocksucker.

question: Okay, cocksucker.
answer: Mamaema. Who is your favorite player?

question: Robinson Cano for the Yankees. I know him brother. And you?
answer: Roberto Clemente.

question: Who is that?
answer: What? You don't know about Clemente?

question: Is Dominican?
answer: Puerto Rican. I can't believe it. This is tragic. Do you know who Babe Ruth is?

question: Baby Ruth? El chocolate?
answer: Hey, how'd it go with that girl the other night?

question: Girl?
answer: Yeah, didn't you have a date, or something?

question: Oh, she no es my girl.
answer: No sweat, bro. We'll find you a little honey on the road. You like The White Stripes?

question: I don't know.
answer: Check it out. "Santos stings Owls with 8 Ks." What kind of shoddy journalism is this? There's nothing' about me in here.

question: Did you ever see "Y Tu Mama Tambien"?
answer: Y tu mama what?

question: Y Tu Mama Tambien... It's Mexican.
answer: No, I don't know this.

question: You have other child...?
answer: He's in Iraq. You like it here in Iowa?

question: Yes. I like... Many new things. Very different.
answer: I bet. You've traveled a long way, huh? God must have something special in mind for you... What happened there?

question: Uh... When I boy... Um... I don't know--
answer: Tell me in Spanish.

question: Okay... When I was little, I wanted to eat some cherries from a tree. It wasn't our tree, and there was a fence to keep us kids away. So I climbed up the fence to knock down some cherries with a stick, but I when I took my first swing-- whoosh. I fell. There was a lot of blood.
answer: Sorry, I just... Sorry. I should help clean up... We have another meeting Thursday... If you can come.

question: I had a good run.
answer: What happened?

question: It's over.
answer: Why?

question: You know the drill. I'm not playing well, so they'll bring up somebody who is.
answer: What about your knee? You just need some more time... You're recovering.

question: Sugar...
answer: When do you leave?

question: They want me to fly back tonight.
answer: Tonight?!

question: But I'm not going back... I gotta cousin in New York.
answer: You're going to New York?

question: How'd you play tonight?
answer: Good, good.

question: I bet you have lots of groupies waiting for you after your games.
answer: I have a few.

question: A few?
answer: Just kidding. I mean I would, but none of these white girls speak Spanish. Marcos plays in Arizona. Lots of Mexicans; everyone speaks Spanish. He has like fifteen girlfriends.

question: Shut up!
answer: He's probably lying though.

question: I bet he's lying.
answer: Jorge went to New York.

question: To the Yankees?
answer: No. Our team cut him loose. He's got a cousin there... I don't know what he's going to do...

question: Shit... What about his family?
answer: It's not right. He got injured playing for them. They owe him another chance. He's worked too hard for too long... I mean he's not a horse.

question: But you can't let it get to you. You've got nothing to worry about. Just keep playing well, and things will be okay.
answer: Yeah... I know. Things will be okay. What is your book?

question: Yeah... I know. Things will be okay. What is your book?
answer: Welcome to the Terrordome. It's about sports and politics.

question: You study at, um, university?
answer: Yeah, I went to Stanford. Studied history and baseball. Did you go to school back in the DR?

question: Yes. Little. Secondaria?
answer: High school?

question: Yes. A little of... high school. But I sign when I have sixteen years.
answer: You signed at sixteen? Wow. So you didn't finish school?

question: If you no play baseball... what you do?
answer: Um... it's hard to say for sure, but I like history, so I'd probably go to grad school... maybe teach someday.

question: These are grandma's from the other night. We missed you at our meeting, Thursday.
answer: Sorry. I forget.

question: It's okay, maybe next time.
answer: You want sit?

question: I gotta go actually, so--
answer: Okay, go.

question: Okay.
answer: What he say?

question: Don't worry about it... Good to see you.
answer: Good to see you, too, Sugar. I'm a little nervous.

question: I know it's hard when you don't perform up to your own expectations for yourself. But you need to learn self- control. Can you understand what I'm saying? You need to learn that your actions have consequences. So we're gonna take the cost of the water unit you broke out of your next check... That's not something your family back home's gonna be too proud of... Is it? So you should think real hard next time. Think about channeling that frustration you're feeling onto the field. Into practice. Channel it into working harder--
answer: --I am work hard! Everyday I work hard.

question: So work harder, goddamnit! You think you're the only one on this team works hard?
answer: I don't understand you. You speak too fast. I just don't understand!

question: Did you hear I made player of the week?
answer: You told me last night.

question: Which one do you use?
answer: That one.

question: Sorry. One room.
answer: For how long?

question: I don't know.
answer: Two hundred a week. First week in advance. Two hundred now.

question: This also please. You speak Spanish?
answer: Of course.

question: Is this your place?
answer: Yeah. Can I help you?

question: I like your work.
answer: Thanks. What are you looking for?

question: Oh, no, I mean... I don't know. I was passing by and thought maybe you might need some help. I know how to make furniture, and--
answer: --I don't have any work right now. Sorry.

question: Right. Okay, thanks for your time. Do you know any other places like this where I might find work?
answer: Have you checked the classifieds?

question: Miguelito, what is going on? Frank called last night. Where are you?
answer: New York.

question: Oh, my God! What are you doing in New York? I don't understand. Your team is looking for you.
answer: I can't play anymore.

question: Are you hurt? What does that mean, you can't play?
answer: No. I'm fine. It just--

question: We've been working for this your whole life, Miguelito. Oh, my God! You're so close. I don't understand...
answer: Don't worry, mom. I have some money. We're going to be okay.

question: You have to go back. Listen, Miguel, my sweet sugar, call Frank. They'll take you back.
answer: I can't go back--

question: Did I raise you like this? Did I raise you to give up?
answer: I didn't give up. I'm starting something new here.

question: What? What are you starting?
answer: I have to go mom. The card's almost out of minutes.

question: Where are you even staying? Miguel--
answer: Don't worry. I'm staying with a friend. I have a new job. It's all good. I'm sending money tomorrow.

question: Miguel--
answer: I love you. I'm sorry. Hey, um, I was in here the other day.

question: And then put it in here with the others. When it's full, set to scrub, and there it is.
answer: Do you know anybody with a room for rent?

question: But I'll ask around, let you know if I hear of anything. You and Jorge used to play baseball together?
answer: Yeah, you like baseball?

question: It's okay. I'd rather watch soccer though... Have you found him yet?
answer: Not yet.

question: He'll be through sooner or later.
answer: How long have you worked here?

question: Two years.
answer: Do you have family here?

question: No. My wife and kids are still in Mexico.
answer: My family's in the Dominican. Hi, um, do you remember me?

question: My family's in the Dominican. Hi, um, do you remember me?
answer: Yeah, but, sorry, I still don't have a job for you.

question: That's okay. I already found one. I'm actually just trying to make a coffee table, and I'd like to buy some wood and supplies.
answer: I don't really sell raw materials...

question: I just moved here, you know, and I don't have a space to work. Do you think I could do some work for you, help you clean up or whatever you need, in exchange for using your shop? You don't have to pay me.
answer: Somebody paying you for the table?

question: No. It's a gift for my mom. Something I like to do.
answer: How old are you?

question: Twenty.
answer: Who taught you to make tables?

question: My dad. He was a carpenter in San Pedro.
answer: Is that where you're from?

question: Yeah.
answer: I grew up in Santiago. What are you doing in New York?

question: I came to work. I used to play baseball.
answer: The whole world plays baseball. My son's sixteen. Won't touch a piece of wood that's not a bat. I never cared for the game, myself. Too slow. Your mom still in San Pedro?

question: Yeah. With my sister and brother.
answer: So, you're telling me that you want to make a table for your mom, then mail it back to her in the Dominican? What's your name?

question: Miguel.
answer: Osvaldo.

question: Hello... Is Sofia at home?... Yeah, it's Miguel again... Can you tell her... Just tell her I called... Where you from? So you never liked baseball? Not even as a kid?
answer: It's okay. Sometimes during the playoffs I'll watch a game or two.

question: Who's your favorite player?
answer: I don't know enough to have a favorite.

question: C'mon, everybody has a favorite player
answer: Fine. Jose Canseco.

question: Jose Canseco!? That's the best you can do?
answer: Okay, what about you?

question: Roberto Clemente.
answer: Never heard of him.

question: Shut up.
answer: What's so special about Clemente?

question: I read this book where he said something like, "If you have the opportunity to help someone and don't, then you're wasting your life." And he was a carpenter too.
answer: Get out of here.

question: For real. He used to make furniture during the off season.
answer: Are you fucking with me? Cause you know I can google this fool right now.

question: Google?
answer: The internet. Don't worry, I'll teach you someday. When did you get released?

question: They didn't release me. I left a few days before the season ended.
answer: You left? When was this?

question: About two weeks ago.
answer: Holy shit. Where are you staying?

question: Oh, you know, with a friend. But if you know somebody who needs a roommate...
answer: Why'd you leave? Do you have any family here?

question: But I'm okay... I have some money saved, a couple friends. I'll go home to visit soon. Do you know a place called Ukraine?
answer: Hey! You owe money. Full week!

question: I know. I have tomorrow. No problem.
answer: Yes, problem. You pay tomorrow or you have big problem.

question: Frank... It's Miguel.
answer: Jesus, Miguel, what the hell happened?

question: Sorry for calling late. I'm in New York.
answer: I heard. You're making me look bad. What are you doing there?

question: I got a job, but I don't know if I'm going to stay...
answer: Where you gonna go? The season's over... Your visa's expired.

question: I know, but I thought maybe I could...
answer: I can talk to Alvarez... But I don't know. Nobody's happy about this.

question: I know. Sorry.
answer: Look, Miguel--

question: I don't know where to go. Fuck you, man!
answer: Fuck you too, bro!

question: What happened to you?
answer: Me? What happened to you?

question: I been looking for you for weeks.
answer: I know. Rafi said you took my old job. Welcome to New York! I called the Higgins to give my new number, but they said you split. I couldn't believe it, man, I had no idea.

question: Things got a little ugly after you left.
answer: We all go through slumps you know.

question: It wasn't a slump.
answer: What was it then?

question: I don't know, but I wasn't gonna wait around for them to throw me out. I'm just saying...
answer: Whatever, man, you wouldn't be saying that shit if you made it.

question: I got the photos you sent, but you'll have to send more.
answer: Okay, mom, but you know it would be a lot easier if you opened an email account.

question: Email? I don't even know how to use the TV!
answer: I'm making a new table for you. It's going to be real nice.

question: I'm sure I'll love it. Thank you.
answer: How's Erica?

question: She's good. Got a job at the factory. Just part-time, though, so she can keep up with school.
answer: And Luis?

question: He's pitching now. You should see him, Miguel, got an arm like his brother.
answer: Yeah, but can he throw a knuckle curve? I miss you, mom. But, I'm working hard. I'll be home soon. Give everyone a hug for me.

question: I will, Sugar. I love you.
answer: I love you, too.

question: I love you, too.
answer: Caballo! This is Miguel from San Pedro.

question: I think so.
answer: Don't worry; he's ready. Felipe! Meet Miguel. They call him Sugar. Felipe played for the Dodgers Triple-A team. Hit a dinger off Pedro once. Twice.
